text: so are we better or worse off after five
years of coalition government not
surprisingly the answer rather depends
who you ask
and how you do the sums using ed
Baldur's calculator while the average
household is sixteen hundred pounds were
soft but using George Osborne's
calculator well the average household is
nine hundred pounds better off confused
what's broadly true is that in the first
half of this parliament there was an
awful lot of austerity the government
increased v80 imposed a public sector
pay freeze and set about curbing
benefits like tax credits and Housing
Benefit on top of that the economy
plunged into recession unemployment
peaked at two-and-a-half million and
household costs like energy bills soared
in these lean years labour was able to
effectively campaign on the so-called
cost of living crisis but in the second
half of this Parliament there's been a
significant turnaround energy bills have
fallen by up to five percent petrol by
more than twenty percent
crucially the economy has bounced back
growing seven times faster than the
French economy and with record levels of
employment and pay at long last
increasing faster than inflation the
truth is perhaps this the cost of living
crisis is certainly receding but for
many families there's still an awful lot
of ground to make up
